headline: Broadcom Stock Tumbles Further
summary: Broadcom shares are starting the week with more declines, following last week's selloff.  Shares in the chipmaker fell about 4% Monday, following the sharp drop Friday in response to the company's earnings report.  In late morning trading, Broadcom had fallen about 16% over the last three trading sessions.

headline: Wall Street Has Lots of Questions. Stock Markets Might Not Like the Answers They Get This Week.
summary: Wall Street could find answers to some of its most important questions over the next five days as the final full trading week of a difficult year looks set to provide key tests to narratives about the economy, artificial- intelligence stocks, and the path of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy.  Investors enter the week, which typically marks the start of a traditional late-December rally, in a cautiously optimistic mood, with market volatility gauges ticking higher and benchmark  Treasury bond  yields trading north of levels seen prior to last week’s interest-rate cut by the U.S. central bank.  Megacap tech stocks also are on the back foot, with declines this month for every member of the so-called Magnificent 7 cohort apart from  Tesla  and big late-week declines for  Oracle  and  Broadcom  following mixed quarterly earnings updates that added to concerns over near-term profitability.

raw.headline: Wall Street Has Lots of Questions. Stock Markets Might Not Like the Answers They Get This Week.
raw.summary: Wall Street could find answers to some of its most important questions over the next five days as the final full trading week of a difficult year looks set to provide key tests to narratives about the economy, artificial- intelligence stocks, and the path of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy.  Investors enter the week, which typically marks the start of a traditional late-December rally, in a cautiously optimistic mood, with market volatility gauges ticking higher and benchmark  Treasury bond  yields trading north of levels seen prior to last week’s interest-rate cut by the U.S. central bank.  Megacap tech stocks also are on the back foot, with declines this month for every member of the so-called Magnificent 7 cohort apart from  Tesla  and big late-week declines for  Oracle  and  Broadcom  following mixed quarterly earnings updates that added to concerns over near-term profitability.

headline: Stock Futures Rebound Following Brutal Tech Selloff
summary: Stocks looked set to edge higher on Monday, clawing back some of their recent losses as investors bought the dip ahead of a slew of economic data and some crucial central bank policy decisions.  “The weakest AI stories are increasingly being punished rather than the pre-September period when AI all went up together,” Deutsche Bank analyst Jim Reid said on Monday.  Shutdown-delayed employment reports for October and November due out Tuesday will give investors a better sense of how the labor market is faring, which could be key to determining if the Federal Reserve carries on cutting interest rates next year.

Shutdown-delayed employment reports for October and November due out Tuesday will give investors a better sense of how the labor market is faring, which could be key to determining if the Federal Reserve carries on cutting interest rates next year.

headline: Bitcoin Struggles to Recover After Tech Appetite Wanes
summary: Bitcoin rose slightly but remained below the key $90,000 level as it struggled to recover meaningfully after hitting a near two-week low overnight. The cryptocurrency has been hit by a rotation away from artificial intelligence-related stocks after results from Oracle and Broadcom last week failed to meet lofty expectations.

headline: Chinese Tech Stocks Stumble Amid Sluggish Sentiment
summary: Chinese chip and tech stocks stumbled as the negative sentiment on Wall Street carried over into Monday's session. "Hong Kong tech is getting hit from both sides—Wall Street's AI hangover is dampening global appetite for growth names, and weak China data is reminding investors that the domestic demand story still isn't healing," Saxo Markets chief investment strategist Charu Chanana said in an email.
